Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned a general overall of some concepts of biology and how they relate to the world and society.

This course was really interesting and taught be a lot about both biological processes and phenomena (such as the science of addiction, the way the brain works and contagious diseases) as well as their social implications.
This class taught me a lot about the basics of biology that will be useful in the real world. It was structured so as to explain everything clearly and succintly
Learned a lot about different aspects of biology, like diseases, famine, plants, climate change, etc. I took AP bio in high school and was looking for an easy science credit and this was pretty good.
I learned about a lot of interesting applications of the biological world to everyday issues and concepts.
I learned about a variety of biological issues -- pertaining to infectious diseases, climate change, biodiversity, genetics, neurobio, and plants -- and their economic, social, and political impacts.

I learned about the biology behind some of the world's most pressing heath and social issues. I also had the opportunity to write a research paper, something I had not done before at the college level.
I learned a lot about social implications of biological developments.

I had never taken biology and so everything I learned was new information. I have really gained great insight into the biological world and am so appreciative for having had the opportunity to learn this stuff, but not in the pressured environment of the bio track.

Broad overview of various biological processes and how they are relevant to us, the earth, and our changing society. Better understanding of easy, should-know topics, like basic plant biology, the way viruses work, how climate change changes ecosystems, etc.

I learned so much science knowledge that is relevant to the world. Not only that, through the sections, I learned the importance of the material that was presented in the class and definitely how to think and share opinions with others to reach a better conclusion.
A wide range of applicable biological concepts. I feel more scientifically well rounded.
I gained a better understanding of how biology effects us in our everyday lives and the impacts that we are having on our environment and what to do in order to reverse this.
i learnt about why climate change is important

Through the three different lecturers, I learned about climate change, brain functions, drugs on the brain, plants, genetics, ocean life, TB, malaria, HIV/AIDS, and a host of other random things. There wasn't really a clear these to this class, but I sort of enjoyed that. I liked learning about something new every time I showed up.
I acquired a basic understanding of the biology behind many public health/policy issues, which will certainly be helpful for me moving forward.

I learned about infections diseases, the brains and interactions between plants and society. The course provides a comprehensive introduction into three unique fields in the sciences and how they are interrelated.
I learned about different topics in biology and issues that arise from them
considering issues from all different angles and perspectives
I learned a lot about a wide range of interesting topics in biology that are relevant today, and their implications in society.
Basic knowledge on various topics
I learned about the social issues behind biology.

I came into the class not knowing too much about the bridge between policy and science, but I learned a lot throughout the course of the semester about the ethical and political implications of different scientific phenomena. Not only did professors Carlson, Gendron, and Koleske provide relevant societal context for their work, but they also linked the importance of learning this science to legislating effectively.
This course felt like a crash course in bio, chem, and environmental science.
I found this course extremely interesting especially for someone who is not very science oriented. It covered a broad array of topics that are very prevalent in our world today

this is a really interesting class that teaches some basic "you should probably know this for like" knowledge! you learn about some major bio topics in the world, and see the "why" of why it's important to society and not just scientist stuff
information about disease, plants, and neurological issues

I learned a ton about a variety of topics rooted in biology, from brain disorders, climate change, the spread of infectious diseases, etc. I didn't only learn the basic underlying biology behind them, but also a lot about the broader social implications.
I learned practical biological information that I could easily apply to my own life that made a lasting impact on what I care about and I prioritize in the world.
How biology surrounds us in our everyday lives
I learned a lot about how diseases can affect the world, and the social and political concerns of science in the modern day.
Greater knowledge about contemporary biological issues facing societies.
Learned a lot more about the biology behind relevant topics and understood how  science can be interdisciplinary
Great overview of Biology and how it affects our world
A basic introduction to some of the more important and interesting topics in biology. Exposure to a number of scientific readings and debates on the ethical side of science.
I learned a great deal of information about the the human body and its cells, plants, and the world and its environment.
Learn to think about science and how it impacts our lives.

Man... too much to list... let's see:
- parts of the human brain
- the pros and cons of monoculture
- gene editing and designer babies
- the history and cause of today's opium crisis
- why leaves change color and fall each year
- how light, water and temperature affect crop production
- vaccine controversy
- the rampant racism behind the crack epidemic
- never do coke
- weed is ok but increases your risk of schizophrenia
I learned the broad picture of current topics in global health, effects of climate change, and impacts of new innovation in food security.
good survey bio course- not getting too in the weeds
I learned a lot about the basics of biology - From different organisms to how the human body functions.
I learned a lot of very interesting statistics about how mental diseases impact the social and economic welfare of its victims.
I loved this class! I am semi-sciency but an Econ major and felt there was a great balance of learning technical science and the social implications of that scientific problem/discovery.
Learned about pressing social issues related to biology such as climate change, genetics, gmo crops and other similar topics.
Bettered my critical thinking when approaching events having to do with biologyrealizing its not just about the biology but also has many other impacts.
Biology
Taught me to think critically about science and apply its consequences to the real world
I learned about various topics like infectious agents, disorders, and plants, and I learned their biological explanation.
A lot about useful applications of biology relating to current events and things that matter.
I learned a lot about climate change and global diseases.
Learned about biology from a lot of different perspectives.
The basic foundations of biology and how they affect the world around us
Various facts about biology across multiple topics ranging from plants to schizophrenia. Caused me to consider biologys implications on society.
Looked a lot about different aspects of biology and how the relate with the world.

Broadly speaking, I learned about global infectious diseases, the human brain and some of its disorders, and the environment  within each of these spheres, lectures centered around issues that are relevant and compelling to hear about.
Interesting biology information that is applicable to our lives.
Learnt about the social, ethical, political relations to contemporary scientific researches.
Basic biology topics
In this course I learned a lot of good, factual information about the topics we went over in class. I felt like everything was explained in a thorough, but easy to understand way.
Basic understanding of wide biology topics
I learned about viruses and bacteria.
I learned about a lot of different topics in science and it was great to be able to take a science that was not too in depth or complicated.
I learned all about some interesting political aspects of biology.
I learnt a lot about the social issues that arise as a result of biological problems and how we can think about approaching them.
I learned about biology and its applications to energy and medicine.
Great general bio overview.
Great knowledge of topics affecting modern day science and society.
I gained a greater knowledge of the biology taught in this class and how it effects the world around us. Learned about what problems we are facing today and how they began.

This course covered a wide variety of topics. I learned about the biology of plants and mutation, the health effects of different drugs and how they have affected society, the biology of diseases and their effects on society, and many more.
Broad knowledge of biological issues affecting society
I learned more about all different aspects of biology, which included global infectious diseases, the brain and plants.

I think I learn about interesting concepts. The course doesn't go to much in depth, but I didn't really expect that in the first place. I learned how to think about biological issues from a sociological prospective, which I think is a useful skill to have.
I gathered more insight about the social ramifications of specific biological concepts/issues.
a breadth of info relating to science, climate change dna and more
basically a review of honors/AP level bio - nice refresher on scientific topics
I thought this was a great way to garner insight into a variety of interesting biological issues.
Learned about the developing biological world and how we interact with it.
A good general sense of the world around us from a microbiological to a biological and environmental perspective.
I learned about a myriad of interesting subjects. As far as skills, though, I'm not sure this class taught anything besides your standard memorization.
I was able to apply my existing knowledge of biology to societal issues.
I learned basic biology of human anatomy, plant biodiversity and the world.
I learned how to analyze biological issues through their social and political effects.
A ton...a great class to take for science credit. You learn about so many interesting examples for each topic covered.
A broader understanding of scientific and biological issues in both a scientific and social/historical context.
We acquired knowledge of basic biological functioning and how this ties into the world and huge events.
I learned about issues in biology and the science and social mechanisms that surround them.
Broad knowledge of a bunch of scientific topics that are socially relevant and topical. Enough depth to remain interesting
Learning the real life applications of biological concepts as they pertain to politics and ethics.
I learned about green energy/global warming/sustainable farming, addiction and schizophrenia, and contagious diseases/viruses. I developed the skills of writing a college level research paper.

I learnt a range of skills in interpreting scientific research and how to write a scientific paper. I learnt a basic survey of biological knowledge, especially the ways in which human interactions with the world can create and solve biological issues. I learnt a lot about the societal impacts of biological topics, such as infectious disease, plant and conservation biology.

Amazing course for non-science majors. I took Bio my freshman year of high school, and this course was not only a refresher but taught me material I would have never been able to learn in high school. Amazing course!
I learned so much about climate change and world diseases. Very informative class

As a non science major I enjoyed gaining insights into interesting socially and politically relevant current issues in science, learning about some of the biology background as well as the applications of this scientific knowledge in daily life.
I gained critical thinking skills and gained insight into the ways biology is intertwined with society
I learned new information about scientific trends and how scientists observe and report these trends.
My critical thinking skills and I expanded my knowledge on the topics of biology
Pretty solid science class for non science majors!
All three professors are really invested and engaging in teaching their material. I think a little more consistency across the three exams would have been more helpful.
Great lectures and clear exams.

Strengths: easy science credit that doesn't have a lot of work, the professors were very good and so nice. They all loved teaching the class so they would make it very interesting and use humor 
weakness: the tests were extremely unfair. You would spend all of class learning about the true biology and biological mechanisms of a topic and the test would ask the most irrelevant, unrelated questions. Also the sections are separate from the class so you don't get to go over class topics or anything, but instead have separate reading assignments and discussions that don't help you understand the information from class.
Great professors! I loved this class. Fair tests, interesting information.

Strengths - fascinating concepts, notes provided on canvas 
weaknesses - lots of information on each exam, graded difficultly

strengths -- covered a lot of complex issues in simple terms, explained wide-reaching consequences of those issues, professors made the content interesting, funny, and engaging to facilitate learning

weaknesses -- sections were wildly different. TAs assigned different readings and talked about different topics in each section, so students had vastly different experiences. section should be a bit more standardized and should relate more closely with the class material.
I liked how there were three different professors who taught on what they were most knowledgeable in. I think there should be more rigorous selection of TAs.
Strength is its discussion sections. Weakness is its focus on very, very specific details of the lectures (on the exams)

This course has great content and is tested very fairly. The professors are all approachable, personable, engaging and very knowledgeable. They provided some complex information in a way that could be understood and created a syllabus that really touched on the most important aspects of biology, the world and people. LEcture was usually fun and engaging.
Strength: easy to follow along. The emphasis is not on deep academic understanding but more a general understanding of real-world processes.

The strength of the course is that the professors put tremendous amount of effort into this class. You can see that. Hence, they are very eager to help you out and adjust to whatever background you may have in the field. I think the weakness of this course is that the transitioning from professors to professors could be a little smoother. I wish there would be a unifying theme or a bridge between the professors.
The professors were all great but the class moves fast and it was hard to study for a test that covered dramatically different topics.
Strengths: THE PROFESSORS! they were so engaged and wanted their students to learn.
Strengths: an interesting Sc credit for non-STEM majors
nothing

Strengths: Prof Carlson presented his material well, Prof Koleski was an all-around good guy and I especially liked his material as a psych major, Prof Gendron was charismatic but his material was the least interesting to me. All three responded to emails quickly and their answers were helpful. Tests were manageable and if you got behind it wasn't difficult to catch up.

Weaknesses: Too many profs and no overall theme. Lectures got boring at times, but the material was easy enough to follow.

The strength of the course was that all of the professors were likable, interesting, and engaging! I was also in the Experience Science section which I loved a lot and thought was incredible. I think the review sessions could be improved upon before exams, and perhaps the exams could be changed so that rather than memorizing a lot of information, students needed to actually understand the general ideas that are presented in class.

Strengths: each of the three professors were very engaging and clearly enjoyed teaching the class. The material was easy to understand and interesting. 

Weaknesses: by nature of being a survey course the class lacks depth and complexity. Moreover, some of the lecture power points included far too many slides making studying difficult and there was no clear evaluative metric for written work.
Super interesting and fun to attend
strength - section where discussion was free-flowing and student-led and we could discuss pretty much anything relevant we wanted to
Strengths: really fun lectures, material easy to understand, interesting readings, low workload

I found the material to be pretty boring, especially for non-biology/STEM majors and the exams often tested for very specific details (detailing biological processes) which definitely could be challenging for students who've never taken a Biology class before or haven't taken Biology since 8th grade. This often gave people who took AP Biology an extreme advantage as these students found the class and the exams super easy. I think the exam questions should have been more open-ended and more focused on the social/ethical implications of Biology which is what the class is designed to teach.

The course was well-organized, especially for a class of its size. The professors were very hands-on and conducted fun activities in class to engage students. However, I do feel like this class could benefit from a more in-depth exploration of the science behind these topics. Some of the topics were covered only superficially (for example, the mental health impacts of marijuana use). In those cases, none of the information presented went beyond common knowledge.

Lecturers were great!

All test answers could be found in the lecture notes, but it was difficult knowing what to study. 

The test review sessions could have been more streamlined. They ended up being just a summary of the lectures.

I liked how it was broken up into three segments. I disliked how in section we discussed topics that were not related to class. They were interesting topics but I think it would have been helpful to discuss things that we were going to be tested on as well
The experience science section is a definite plus. The review sessions were messy and unorganized though.
the lectures were super interesting and fun and the sections were fun as well

It would be nice if it could be made more clear from the beginning as to what kind of content will be on the tests. I was always a little confused as to whether thered be more biology or social issues on the exams.

This was by far my favorite course I took this semester. The curriculum was so relevant and interesting, the lectures were engaging, and it wasn't too much work. My favorite aspect of the course though was by far the professors. Professor Carlson was incredibly engaging and enthusiastic and really started the semester off with great energy. I didn't think that any professor could live up to him, but I was equally as impressed by Professors Koleske and Gendron. It was evident that all three were extremely passionate about both their areas of study but also about teaching undergrads. I mainly took this class as a science credit, but came out of it really feeling excited about science and a lot of these biological issues. I would say that there were no weaknesses.
The professors are very engaging and present interesting, timely, information.
Lectures are sections are great, sections should relate more to the lecture
Could do a better job preparing students for what is on the exams.

The strengths of the course are that the lecturers are, for the most part, engaging. However, a major problem with the course was the lack of clarity in what we were expected to know for exams versus what was presented on slides.
Great and clear lectures, although feedback on exams would be good. Also discussion sections seemed quite disconnected with the lectures

Strengths were that lectures were interesting, engaging and easy to follow along with. All 3 of the lecturers were entertaining and funny and made classes interesting and worth going to. Course material was never too complicated and while the tests did require some time to prepare for, it was straight memorization. Concepts were all very interesting and sections led to pretty meaningful discussions.

Strengths of this course include its professors and teaching assistants. Also the material in this course is interesting a enjoyable to learn. A weakness of the course is the set up of the review sessions  before the exams.
Loved the lectures and sections.

Strength: Workload is very manageable, lectures can be enjoyable.

Weaknesses: A heavy amount of notes are needed in order to do well.

Strengths: John Carlson and Josh Gendron
Weaknesses: their office hours were up science hill so I never went
The grading is random and sometimes unfair. Although improved by the curve at the end, there is no reason it couldn't be improved.

I think the quality of the TFs varies a lot from year to year. One friend told me last year that her TFs were great and that their review sessions for the exams were super helpful. However, this year the TFs were kind of a mess. The first review session in particular was absolutely useless - the TFs were inaudible, and what I could hear was not at all helpful. They got better as the semester went on.
Great subject matter but discussion in section could have been better
Strengths - well conducted with great Professors, organized, efficient.
I think that the lectures could present information with greater detail and specificity to help prepare for the exams.

The course was not really focused on the social and political impacts of biology related issues. The syllabus very much pitched the course differently, but that was not the case. The exams were mostly testing memorization of the slides we went over in class, and not so much for understanding. This was very hard itself since the professors went over a lot of material in a 50 minute lecture. Furthermore, the lectures included very complex biological processes that we often just breezed over, benefitting those who had a strong biology background. My biggest problem with the course, however, was section. Section was completely unrelated to class and the exams, despite being mandatory. I really don't think I gained anything from section, but did end up more confused. 

This being said, the professors are extremely charismatic and very willing to help you. They really try to make this class as fun as they can.

There is little connection between sections and lecture/exams. Section was the most interesting part of the class, so it would be nice to incorporate some of that material into the exams. Seems like the exams, some more than others, focused much more heavily on science and avoided the societal aspects.
Sections seemed a little pointless. Could be bettered by making them really interesting or directly connected to what were learning in class.
it was cool material i just thought the exams were misleading. many of the exam questions were too specific for the amount of material we had to learn.

Strengths: amazing TA, good lectures
weaknesses: unclear what should be prioritized when studying
Good TA and section
The lectures were great and I really enjoyed the content!!
I think the course was very informational and interesting, but I wish section was focused more on reviewing material from the lectures instead of talking about readings.
Its a fine bio class. When teaching about schizophrenia to a group of people of the age most likely to be experiencing early symptoms, maybe teach with that in mind
Very interesting
It was very diverse in topics and content and perspective.

This class was very engaging and the professors present the material in a way that is fun and easy to digest, I never wanted to fall asleep or wished that I hadn't gone to lecture. There is a lot of information, but they counteract that by giving learning objectives to give a general overview of what is being taught.
The lectures could have been linked together better and section couldve been related to lecture
Hard to study for given the wide range of topics covered over one exam. Lectures were very enjoyable. Grading of exams wasnt always standardized.
Really fun course that is taught well.

I have no complaints about this course; I loved how each lecture was about something different, and we didn't dive too deeply into any given topic, so the breadth of this survey course was really quite satisfactory.

The way it was divided for the tests. One classroom had a clock and the other didnt which is the reason why I had a hard time managing my time and I think gives one group an advantage over the other. We were only told when we had 15 min left in the classroom without the clock and no other warnings.

The professors were amazing, they are all very passionate about what they teach which is what made each class interesting. However, creating a more interactive environment could improve students' attentiveness in class.

Strengths: amazing professors, interesting topics
Weaknesses: could have been better resources for test prep

Strengths- all the professors were engaging, did a good job explaining the scientific concepts we went over, and were pretty accessible to students even though the lecture was huge

Weakness- the sections were pretty interesting, but I never felt like they tied in to the lectures that well or helped us on any of the midterms.

Strengths Professors, lectures, topics

Weaknesses No test review, preparation, or organization (needlessly specific grading too)

I really liked how we learned about a lot of different topics in science and were exposed to many different areas of the field. I did think the time we got on the midterms was a little short for the amount that was needed to think and write.

Strengths - very clear lecture slides and simple diagrams 
Weaknesses - none
Strengths were the professors and the material. Weaknesses would be that the exams were difficult.
Great and engaging lectures. Could be improved by giving students more practice questions.

The teaching is simply incredible and the topics covered were all interesting. I wouldn't change anything outside of making sure all the questions on the tests truly match material we have studied (there was one page of questions on test 1 or 2 that was largely on subjects we hadn't covered).
The lectures very pretty engaging and interesting. They review session could be structured better. The grading of the tests were a little sketchy.

I felt this course did a very good job connecting the material in lecture to section meetings, and went into depth accordingly. I felt the professors were very interesting and clear as well. However, I thought the review sessions for the test did not help much and some of the test questions were confusing/misleading.

All of the lecturers were really engaging. They presented the material in a way that was easy to understand for non STEM majors. I also had the opportunity to get dinner with two of the lecturers and other students, which was great.
I really enjoyed this course.
I think it was fine. Maybe better organization of review sessions//streamlining the combination of lectures, readings, and section. Unclear, I know, but I don't rly want to specify
I thought it was a good balance of biology and social issues. I kind of wish the seminars focused more on the biology stuff sometimes.
Strengths include interesting topics and having multiple professors added new content. The new professors however made it slightly confusing

Strengths: very accessible to someone without a science background 

Weaknesses: some professors were more engaging than others, section tended to be very dull and prescriptive
This course gives someone a good view into the intersection of biology and everyday life. However, the course can be a bit disorganized at times.

It is strong in the sense that it felt to me, as a humanities oriented student who is not interested in pursuing a STEM related career, the material taught and the way in which it was taught felt very relevant, applicable, and engaging to me in the context of my own life. It was both understandable and challenging, and caused me to think critically about contemporary issues from different perspectives instead of feeling confused or bored, which I have felt with other "distributional requirement" related classes.

I think this course was amazing, and did not have any weaknesses. The professors and TFs were amazing, the coursework and exams were divided up nicely, and the material very interesting. A great course for non-science majors!
I felt the course was great.
Good lectures, section didnt add very much. Lecture could have been 1hr 15 with no section.
Weakness: lecture notes can be more concise

I think sections could be more geared towards discussing the class material and reviewing or the topics we discuss should align with our class theme each week because I felt section to be a little unhelpful for the class overall.
The discussion sections are always very interesting and well led. The lectures are good too. The professors are super nice.

Given that this course largely attracts non-STEM students, I thought that this course was very well designed to teach basic and very relevant biological topics that it is important to have some literacy in without going into technical depth beyond the reach of the average student. All of the lectures were very informative and interesting and covered all of the most important and current issues in science and the world right now. 
The weaknesses of the course lay in the preparation for the exams. The review sessions were very poorly structured and the discussion sessions were so relaxed it was kind of a joke and they were pretty pointless. It was still possible to do well in the exams because they stuck tightly to the lectures, with the exception of the final exam which quite unfairly required knowledge not on the slides and the review sessions did not help fill in these gaps.

Strengths are that its genuinely designed for non STEM majors. That doesn't mean that we don't actually learn science, but that the science we learn is presented in ways that make its applications apparent. It's not always super interesting and not always easy but I actually feel like I've learned valuable things about the world that I'm a lot better for.
Strength is the teaching style and how interactive the classes were. It could be improved by more in depth slides in some cases
There is a lot of information to cover in one semester, but the instructors always kept lectures fun and interactive.

The TA review sessions were the worst review sessions I have ever been to as a student. It did not at all feel like the TAs were eager to present the material to the students and encourage them to do well. They lacked public speaking skills and passion. On the other hand, I enjoyed the professors very much and thought they broke down the material in a way that made sense.
Yes!
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who wants to acquire a baseline understanding of some fundamental biological concepts and their real-world implications.
Yes, it's a great science credit and class.

If you're looking for an easy science credit, yes. But know that the class and workload is super easy but the tests are difficult. I took AP bio in high school so learning the information was a breeze. The tests however, asked the most ridiculous and unrelated questions to the point where I sometimes questioned if we even learned the information it was asking for.
Definitely! Such a great and relevant class.

yes! great science credit and I felt like I walked away with a lot more knowledge on biology-related issues than I had going into the semester. I learned more about GMOs, biofuels, and other hot-button issues I had no idea about.
I would, because I feel fulfilled in how much I know about pressing scientific issues.
Yes, interesting science credit, but too much detail sometimes.

This is a great option for a non-STEM major looking for a science credit. The workload is minimal outside of class and section, and the exams are generally straightforward as long as you've studied the lecture notes. The TFs can be picky with grading in terms of looking for specific terms to get full points, but other than that the course is not too difficult. Definitely take this as a science credit.
I would definitely recommend this course! The content is so interesting and it is delivered in a fun and engaging way.
Sure, if you need a science credit. Non-cumulative exams, no problem sets, one short essay, and weekly section make for a fun experience.
Yes, if you need a science credit but have trouble with science subjects, this class will teach you the basics without overwhelming you.
I do. Whatever your background is in science, you will learn so much. The professors are just amazing.
yes, it offers broad insight to very applicable modern science concepts for a non-science major.
Yes, the topics we covered were interesting and the workload was manageable. Great Sc class for non-STEM majors.
yes, it is easy science, must be honest that i did get fucked by the exams but i put in so little

Yes definitely - in terms of a science credit, it's a great way to gain exposure to specific biological processes that are framed within a larger social relevance context. The material is engaging, the lectures are interesting, and the work is reasonable.
Great class, super easy science gut, especially if you're premed and want a naptime twice a week that boosts your science GPA.

This was a fine science gut. It wasn't my first choice (I was in media and medicine in modern america and then they decided to cap the class the day before schedules were due, pas bien), but this class was a fine alternate. I went into it salty because it wasn't my first choice, but I was able to catch up on the four lectures I missed while I was in the other class and ended up finding a lot of the material interesting. If you're not a science person, this is a great way to get a science credit, as its 60% bio and 40% social implications. Definitely not the most exciting class I've taken, but it fulfilled a science credit and I did learn a good bit of information that I didn't know before.
Ultimate gut. Spent less time on this class than I did on ONE SINGULAR CS323 pset. Use this to pad your schedule and harvest that Sc credit you definitely wont regret it.
I would recommend this course to another student. The workload was manageable, material wasn't too hard to grasp, and overall, I feel that I learned a lot.
I would recommend this course to fulfill the science requirement for someone not planning to major in sciences but who wants a basic foundation in the subject.
Yes it was super interesting and the lectures were fun to attend
gut
yes - great science credit
Yes! It may sound like a gut course to fulfill your science credit, but, although relatively easy, you learn A LOT about a bunch of very interesting topics.

No, I found the material to be pretty boring, especially for non-biology/STEM majors and the exams often tested for very specific details (detailing biological processes) which definitely could be challenging for students who've never taken a Biology class before or haven't taken Biology since 8th grade. This often gave people who took AP Biology an extreme advantage as these students found the class and the exams super easy. I think the exam questions should have been more open-ended and more focused on the social/ethical implications of Biology which is what the class is designed to teach.
Also, it definitely isn't a gut for non-biology oriented students or students who haven't taken AP Biology with 3 EXAMS AND A PAPER. not an engaging class AT ALL.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student who's at least slightly interested in the policy implications of science. Even though I considered myself someone with a hefty science background, I still enjoyed learning about the nuances of infectious disease spread, plants and their use in renewable energies, etc. The workload was very manageable and the lectures were enjoyable.
Yes, very interesting material covered!
Yes for someone who needs a science credit that is engaging and still a challenge
Yes! It's an fun and interesting science credit for non-science majors

This course is a wolf in sheep's clothing. You make think shearing off the wool requires no experience in the craft at all, but this sheep really bites back. Please do not take this course as a science gut unless you are good at memorizing things like you probably did back in AP Bio. The midterms are much trickier than expected and the final essay is a real pain in the gluteus maximus. You have been warned.
yes! it was a very manageable science and the instructors cared a lot
If youre looking for an accessible and maneagable science credit, then take this. You do learn a lot of interesting stuff.

I would absolutely recommend this course to any student. It's a great science credit that isn't too much work but is extremely relevant and interesting. The professors are all amazing and I actually learned a ton of information that I've found has already come up in my every day life.
Yes, I loved the class.

I would definitely recommend this course if you're a non-science major looking for a Sc credit. It was engaging! I often found myself surprised after lectures thinking "wow, that was pretty cool information." I am the least science-y person, but somehow this was not a terrible experience. I didn't really push myself and put in 100% effort, so I don't think I got as much out of it as I could have. But if you show up to every lecture and pay attention, you can do well in this course. The professors really try to engage non-STEM people and they do a good job of it. Definitely a good Sc credit!
Absolutely, great intro bio class
Yes, very interesting class, low workload
I would probably recommend the course to another student.
Yes definelty very engaging
Yes, it's a great overview course

Take this course if you are a humanities major in need of a science credit. It is perfectly designed for non-STEM majors since there are no problem sets. The tests are all based on learning the material well and being able to write out responses to simple memorization questions. There is one short paper that does not take too long to write if you can find an interesting topic.
Yes, Id recommend this course to another student because Ive found found it very interesting and Ive simply enjoyed taking this class.
Yes! Very interesting science credit.

If you want an easy science credit, sure. Lectures were relatively engaging and none of the concepts are too hard. That being said, you do have to attend lecture and study for exams to get a good grade. If you do those two, it is unlikely you will get a bad grade; exams mostly test route memorization of the specifics of lectures.

Yes. This class was honestly so much fun and the lectures were absolutely fascinating. All non-STEM majors should take this course. It is the IDEAL science credit: not very stressful, but at the same time, highly relevant, informative and educational.
Take it if you need an easy SC.

Yes! And take the Experience Science section!!!!! I don't understand why you wouldn't do it - it's less work (no readings) and so much fun. It's actually a blast and one of the highlights of my semester. The field trips are really well thought out and are honestly just a lot of fun.
Fully recommend this course.
I would- a great science course for non-science majors.
Yes - good basic level biology class that fulfills the science credit.
If someone is looking to explore science that doesnt usually take interest in the subject, then they should take this course!
Yes!
I would not recommend this course. Even though it is pitched as an intro course, it is structured in way to benefit those with a strong background biology.
Good science credit if youre good at memorizing things
Yes, you learn about global issues and interesting ways to think about these issues.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who needs a fairly medium-level science credit, but ONLY if you are good at brute memorization. Otherwise you will have a hard time.
Yes
Of course, very fun material nice workload
Yes, especially if they haven't taken AP Biology in high school but still want a science credit where they will learn about important topics. I loved the discussion sections!
I would recommend it to them if they are interested in learning the topics taught, but because of the teaching style, Id tell them to be cautious.

If you're looking for a gut, this is not exactly a gut. I read a lot of reviews that said this before I took the class because I assumed that I am a genius and everyone who said the class wasn't a gut was my intellectual inferior. Not so. It's not hard, but you can't fart around and get an A. Practice tests will have questions like "what part of the plant is the red part of the strawberry?" but real tests will have questions like "explain the chemical process by which the nasal ingestion of goat ovaries inhibit serotonin uptake" or whatever.  In other words, it's all fun and games until you take the test, for which you probably aren't prepared because you think you're a genius and didn't study the practice test that ultimately was no help anyway. Take it if you're appropriately humble and hardworking. And scene.
Its the definition of a gut bio class. No reading. Exams are just memorizing lecture slides.
Yes, good for people interested in bio
Yes, it was great.
Yes, this course is amazing and it made me more interested in biology. If anything, take it for a fun science credit, but it's a lot more than that.
Yes
Yes because it is a doable science credit for those who are not good at or are uninterested in sciences.
I would recommend this class to anyone looking to fulfill their SC requirement. Its engaging and very interesting.

I'd recommend this course if you're looking for a light workload and a few little interesting tidbits here and there. If you're looking for an intellectually challenging Sc credit, or something that'll really open your eyes, this isn't for you.
Yes, it is incredibly interesting and not super difficult.

Yes- interesting topics, great professors, and information very digestible. Still, tests are harder than one might expect so if youre looking for an A, go to office hours and study very hard. But a B+ can be achieved with relatively little work/prep
Id recommend it to anyone looking for a science credit that requires about the workload of maybe an honors science class in high school.
Yes, but be ready for how specific the tests are
Yes! I loved this class. The way it connected to real-world issues and things you can talk to other people about because its soooo cool.
Yes I would recommend this course to a student that is looking for an interesting science credit. This class is perfect for people who are not very strong in the sciences.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course. If you are a non-STEM person who really liked Bio in high school it will definitely be a very interesting course that looks at things like the opioid epidemic or GMOs from both a biological and a more social perspective. The professors are great and very interested in teaching the course. The exams are very memorization focused.
Yes! It teaches you a lot about the world and major social issues and gives you a lot to talk about in conversation.
I absolutely loved this course. 1000 x better than my last science credit. Aimed at non science majors and makes you LOVE science
no
Yes. Great science for non science majors

I would definitely recommend this course to those seeking a science credit that focuses on the social and societal elements of these topics. You will leave with an actually actionable amount of knowledge that you won't want to forget.
Yes, interesting and engaging. A good biology class for non super sciencey kids.

Yes, I would recommend this course because I felt it was very interesting and the topics were all something I felt I could connect to in some way, which helped in learning the material. I also felt it gives a very good base knowledge of different factors affecting life in our world.
Yes
Yes! Take it of you are a non STEM major. It is an interesting science credit that does not require much knowledge on science or biology.
I would recommend this course to another student.
ABSOLUTELY! learn a lot in a very accessible way
Yeah, if you put a reasonable amount of time into it you'll actually get a ton out of this class.
Yes. Very interesting and low work load.

As a humanities person this was the most interesting SC credit I could think of and find, but the class requires work if you care to have a 'decent' grade by Yale standards at the end. If not, just pass the class and enjoy the material that interests you!
Yes; any student looking to apply biology to political science or other such fields.
Yes, I would. The information covered in this class was very interesting and the lecturers were very good.
Yes, if you are looking for a science credit that examines the intersection of biology and everyday life.
Yes. If you need a science credit (or even just want to learn more about biology) this is the perfect class. Basically an AP Bio course but in less depth and with many more interesting examples.
Yes, I'd recommend it to a non STEM major looking for a science course that is both manageable and incredibly engaging.
I would recommend this course to any non-science major that is is looking for an interesting class for a science credit. The professors are amazing!
Yes, its a really great concept, and I think there should be similar physics and chemistry courses for non-STEM majors.
Yes! Good science credit, doable for non-STEM people, not too much reading (and you could get away without doing it all). Interesting even though somewhat basic science-wise
Great course for non-science majors who are just tryna graduate.
Yes, I think the material is very interesting especially for non-science majors looking for a fun science class.
Definitely.
I would recommend this course as a great easy science credit. If you want to become more scientifically literate at a dinner-table conversation level then this is the course for you.
Yes! lovely class

Yes, if you're non STEM this is perfect science credit in my opinion. Not because it's super easy, but because the material makes sense. At almost no point will you find yourself questioning why you're learning what you're learning because the professors go out of their way to make it applicable.
This was a fun class. I'm not sure if I am more scientifically literate than I was before, but I certainly am more versed popular science.
YES! If you know how to memorize you can do well in the class.
I would recommend this course to non science majors looking for an interesting and engaging science credit that isn't too time consuming.
This is a good class for a general overview of scientific topics.
Yes, but the exams do not reflect the level of detail of the lectures and the answers for the exam demand far more understanding than the professors provided.
